name: Ashland Springs Hotel

reviews.text: My husband grew up in Ashland and still calls Ashland Springs Hotel the Marc Anthony : )
reviews.title: Married at the Springs!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We were married at the Springs on August 6th, 2006, after a year of planning. The wedding planner, Anne, was amazing throughout the process. Answer all my crazy emails promptly, emailed or mailed all the pertinent information, more than once sometimes, and the staff was amazing!
reviews.title: Charming historic hotel
Sorry, we had a good time.
reviews.text: I had a lot of control in planning the ceremony and reception. We stayed in the hotel the two nights previous and the night of the wedding in the honeymoon suite. We were married in the garden, had cocktail hour in the conservatory, and the reception in the reception hall. The reception hall is a bit gaudy, but not unbearable, so we decided to skip a lot of decorations there and focus on the natural beauty of the location. And then it hailed and rained immediately following the ceremony! But, being Oregon, this was expected, so we took pictures in Lithia Park beforehand.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Weddings during high season occurred 2-3 a week, so book early!!! Menu’s for receptions of all kinds are very workable. Anne, the coordinator, was so willing to change whatever we needed, which was so helpful!
reviews.title: Book a Special Package!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Opted for no alcohol reception, except for 1 mixed drink during cocktail hour. Brought in our own keg ($100 to tap, but still cheaper than the hotel prices for getting a keg). Brought own wine ($10 to tap each bottle, still cheaper for us to bring our favorite family wine). Allowed guests to purchase other beers of their choice. Basically, the point is, they are SO willing to work with the customer to find what will work.
reviews.title: Small but warm and charming

likes.liked: — Great location and history of the hotel.

reviews.text: Agree with other comments, Lobby beautiful, queen bed rooms tiny but functional and location is prime. Problem was at check out when I presented with a bill of over $2800 (should have been less than $285). Two long distance charges were on the bill from day of check-in (when I wasn't even in the room)- each for identical amounts and each over $900. Objected to chgs & was told front desk had no authority to change bill so had to wait for manager. Manager arrived, admitted they had phone probems, said he fixed bill and walked away. 2nd bill still showed balance of over $1800 (which again I objected to). 2nd time manager came down he was quite abrupt and insisted that if I subtracted one figure from the other I would arrive at the amount I actually owed. took over 1/2 hour to finally resolve their error with no apology offered by that manager at any time. Like the title says, review your bill at checkout carefully!
reviews.title: watch that check out billl
Beautiful Hotel with an exceptional restaurant
reviews.text: side note: once home, I e-mailed the incident details to the attention of the general manager who did send me a gift certificate for a free nights lodging to compensate me for hassle...

The Ashland Springs is a nicely restored small-scale hotel. The staff were very pleasant, nice continental breakfast, free parking, great location. The room itself was small, but we hardly spent anytime in there except to sleep.
reviews.title: Ask and you shall recieve

reviews.text: The highlight of our trip to this hotel was dinner in their new restaurant 'Larks'. We had a fantastic meal here. We had dinner here on New Year's Day and the place was hopping. Great food and wine, and the chocolate desserts were exceptional.
reviews.title: LOVED the Ashland Springs Hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We've attended the Shakespeare festival in Ashland several times, but this was the first time we stayed at the Ashland Springs Hotel. Convenience to the theaters can't be beat. The hotel's parking lot in back made this truly a one-stop holiday. We had a charming room on the top (9th) floor, with great views of downtown and the surrounding hills. Space is a little tight, but this is, after all, an old hotel, and building renovations have been done tastefully. We had a corner room, and I suspect these are the ones to ask for, if you have a choice. We found the accommodations more than adequate, and the pretty decor and amenities made for a very pleasant stay. Members of the staff were friendly and helpful. Before the theater, we had dinner at the hotel's restaurant, Larks. Our meals were delicious (duck breast, pork loin), and the atmosphere was upscale but not fussy. We'll certainly consider staying here when we next plan a trip to Ashland.
reviews.title: Charm and Convenience for Theatergoers

likes.liked: — historic charm and convenience to theaters
likes.disliked: — a bit crowded during continental breakfast service

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I stayed at the Ashland Springs Hotel for one night on our way from Seattle to Monterey, California. The historic building has been lovingly restored with a charming decor, but it is not a good value.
reviews.title: Overpriced, tiny rooms, but cute

reviews.text: The rooms are tiny, about on a par with what you might expect in London or Manhattan. Ours barely had enough space for the queen-sized bed. On the plus side, the decor is sweet, a theme of birds and flowers in an Edwardian style. Our room was painted in a cheerful yellow and white scheme. Toiletries in the small bathroom were nicer-than-average, and I especially liked the sachet of lavendar "bath tea" that was included. We also had a lovely view across the Rogue River Valley. The hotel is in an absolutely central location, great for walking around Ashland. The front desk staff were friendly. Breakfast was included, though we did not eat it because we were in a hurry to get on the road in the morning.
reviews.title: Historic Hotel gave me bad vibrations

reviews.text: I just felt that $195 per night was too much for a room that small.
reviews.title: Nice style; Great service; Great views
Not happy
reviews.text: We stayed at the Ashland Springs Hotel over the Memorial Day Holiday. The hotel is what you would expect in an old historic building. The rooms are smaller than average (approx 200 sqft) so things are very tight. The location is great if you want to be right down in the heart of beautiful Ashland. But, the big drawback was a continuous high pitched vibration sound coming from the air handling unit. Turning the unit off, did not stop the noise. And, the front desk literally said, "oh yeah, well that is a problem that every room has. We can't do anything about it". They were nice enough to give us a free meal at the adjoining restaurant. But, sleep was impossible without using earplugs. It's that loud and annoying. I would hope that the hotel management will look into rectifying this apparent problem that effects every room, according to the front desk. It is a very cute hotel, if you don't mind a very tight quarters.

description: Elegantly restored historic landmark in the heart of downtown Ashland offers seventy tastefully appointed, non-smoking guest rooms, Waterstone Spa & Salon, English garden,banquet/conference space and Larks Restaurant. Calming colors & decorations evoke an era of relaxed comfort and elegance. Guests are pampered with superb service and luxurious surroundings.
